Class GameObject

  • java.lang.Object
    • GameObject

  • public class GameObject
extends java.lang.Object
    Models an 'object' that is rendered in the game display. Each object has a "bounding box" defined by its top left and bottom right corners. Each object has a speed in the x and y directions, which can be changed the set and accel methods. Subclasses may add additional behavior as necessary. Subclasses should NOT implement rendering behavior; that is to be implemented by classes that use GameObjects.
    Author:
    sdexter72

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      GameObject(int height, int width)
      Initialize object with top corner at (0,0), with given height and width, and initial speed 5 in the x-dimension
      GameObject(int initX, int initY, int height, int width, int xSpeed, int ySpeed)
      Initialize object with top corner, height, width, and initial x- and y-speed
      GameObject(java.awt.Point topLeft, java.awt.Point bottomRight, int xSpeed, int ySpeed)
      Initialize object with top and bottom corners and initial x- and y-speed

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void accelX(int x)
      Increase the GameObject's speed in the x dimension
      void accelY(int y)
      Increase the GameObject's speed in the y dimension
      void bounce()
      IMPLEMENT THIS: What should an object do if it reaches the boundary of the game space? (Of course, you can override this implementation if your subclasses should behave differently)
      static boolean collide(GameObject object1, GameObject object2)
      IMPLEMENT THIS! Should return true if object1 and object2 have collided.

      int getHeight()

      int getWidth()

      Set the GameObject's speed in the x dimension
      void setYSpeed(int ySpeed)
      Set the GameObject's speed in the x dimension
      void step()
      Changes the location of the object for the next "animation frame"
